Award.AwardTitle: RI: Doctoral Student Consortium at the Twenty Fourth International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support of the Doctoral Student Consortium at the Twenty Fourth International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning (ICCBR'16) to be held at Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, USA, from October 31st through November 2nd 2016. ICCBR is an international conference series covering all aspects of research on case-based reasoning, such as memory, problem solving, decision making, learning, recommender systems, analogy, creativity, and applications in industry, business and government. Research on case-based reasoning often is interdisciplinary, with connections to artificial intelligence and intelligent agents, cognitive science and cognitive computing, human-centered computing and interactive systems, and human learning as well as machine learning.

With the resurgence of cognitive systems cognitive computing as evidenced by IBM's Watson system and Apple?s Siri program among many others, the ICCBR community is growing once again. The ICCBR conferences attempt to foster research carried out in the original spirit of AI, which aimed to design and implement computer programs that exhibited the breadth, generality, and flexibility often observed in human intelligence on one hand, and use the design of AI systems for insights into human intelligence on the other. We expect ICCBR'16 to significantly increase our understanding of case-based cognitive systems, and add momentum to the development of new theories, techniques and tools for case-based cognitive computing. The conference sessions and workshops will help develop human research capital by enabling interactions between senior and junior researchers and catalyzing new collaborations. The doctoral consortium will increase the exposure and visibility of young graduate student researchers in these areas, and train them by providing early input and feedback in the field in an interactive and constructive environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Case-Based Reasoning (CBR) is a branch of artificial intelligence as well as cognitive science, with many applications in education, healthcare, and other domoains Thus, research on CBR often is interdisciplinary. The International Conferences on Case-Based Reasoning (ICCBR) are the major annual international and interdiscinipnary conferences on CBR.

The main goals of this NSF project were (1) to help train a group of doctoral students in research on CBR and (2) to help connect them to the CBR research community. The main objectives were to help a small number of selected US graduate students to participate in the doctoral consortiums associated with ICCBR 2016, 2017, and 2018, as well attend the main conferences.

We organized a doctoral student consortium at the 24th International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning (ICCBR 2016; http://iccbr.gatech.edu/iccbr16/index.html). PI Goel was chair of the conference. The consortium was held on October 31, 2016 (http://iccbr.gatech.edu/iccbr16/doctoral.html). It was chaired by two senior CBR researchers: Chair: Sarah Jane Delany, Dublin Institute of Technology in Ireland; and Co-chair: Sefania Montani, University of Piemonte Orientale in Italy. Jonathan Rubin from PARC, USA, gave an invited talk at the consortium. We used part of this grant to support the paricipation of US students in the ICCBR 2016 DCS. Later, we applied for and received a no-cost-extension for the remaining funds.

ICCBR 2017 organized its own DCS in Trondheim, Norway (http://www.iccbr.org/iccbr17/students.html). We used part of this grant to support the paricipation of US students in the ICCBR 2017 DCS and ICCBR 2017. Later, we applied for and received a no-cost-extension for the remaining funds.

ICCBR 2018 too organized its own DCS in Stockholm, Sweeden (http://iccbr18.com/doctoral-consortium/. We are another part of this grant to support the paricipation of US students in the ICCBR 2018 DCS and ICCBR 2018.

The main outcome is that about 30 doctoral students, including about half dozen from the US, have received training in CBR research and have become members of the research community. The participating students are now active conducting research on CBR.


Last Modified: 02/18/2019
Modified by: Ashok K Goel
